JavaScript's cryptic 'this' - what, when and why

November 30, 2017

Before MDN started to organize their JavaScript documentation, finding answers to your JavaScript questions often landed you on Stack Overflow.

Welp, these days MDN has mostly done away with that practice, that is, except if you‚Äôre looking for answers around the usage of JavaScript‚Äôs this keyword.

The documentation is great, it really is, but it‚Äôs not exactly full of helpful, real-world examples. So I thought I‚Äôd put together a few tips and tricks about the ever so magical this keyword.

Old-skool JS

‚ÄúBack in my day we had to alert out our objects!‚Äù

Ok, so yeah, if you run console.log(this) in your dev console you‚Äôll generally see that by default, this = Window{}. Super helpful‚Ä¶?

It gets more interesting when you check the value of this inside a function:


function mahFunc(){
    console.log(this);
}

mahFunc();
// Window{}

You should still see the Window object. Ok so, nothing new here.

But what if you add 'use strict'?

function mahFunc(){
    'use strict'
    console.log(this);
}
// undefined

Hmm.

Ok now, but what if you call mahFunc() on the Window global (since it‚Äôs a global function)?

function mahFunc(){
    'use strict'
    console.log(this);
}

window.mahFunc();
// Window

Huh?

Strict mode is a funny beast, but it generally makes errors more obvious and cleans up your JavaScript. Something not mentioned in the MDN docs is that bundlers/loaders/concatenators like Webpack/Browserify, may have strict mode enabled by default. You might end up with some wacky loader that enables it with out you knowing. So keep an eye out if you ever see your this call returning something funny.

Call me plz

Ok so this in a global context is weird, but who doesn‚Äôt use objects and ES2015 classes these days? If you‚Äôd like to use a different value for this, (as-in not undefined or Window) inside your function, you can pass a context with .call() and .apply(). I always remember these with ‚Äòyadda-yadda.prototype.call()‚Äô.

function mahFunc() {
  console.log(this);
}

const config = {
    stepOne(){
        //do step one
    },

    stepTwo(){
        //do step 2
    }
}

mahFunc.call(config);

//{stepOne: ∆í, stepTwo: ∆í}

And there you go. this references the object passed in argument to .call(). Cool right?

This way you‚Äôre able to specify a context for a function. It‚Äôs super handy and what a lot of frameworks and bundlers use internally ‚Äì check out your Webpack bundles!

I won‚Äôt go over all the possible cases/uses of this, there‚Äôs quite a few and the MDN doc is really good.

It‚Äôs important to remember this ?.
